nodes.text: 23.3 Internationally Integrated Capital Markets

Does the value of a foreign investment depend on the currency we use in the analysis? To address this important question, we will develop a conceptual benchmark based on the assumptions that any investor can exchange either currency in any amount at the spot rate or forward rates and is free to purchase or sell any security in any amount in either country at their current market prices. Under these conditions, which we term
When any investor can exchange currencies in any amount at the spot or forward rates and is free to purchase or sell any security in any amount in any country at its current market prices.
internationally integrated capital markets
, the value of an investment does
not
depend on the currency we use in the analysis.

Consider a share of Vodafone Group, PLC, trading on the London Stock Exchange. Vodafone does not pay dividends and you expect the share of stock to have a value of £260 in one year. The price of this share of stock on the London Stock Exchange is the present value of this cash flow using the cost of capital of a local investor. Assuming that the appropriate cost of capital for Vodafone is 13%, then we have:

nodes.text: Now any U.S. investor who actually purchased a share of Vodafone would have to convert the future pounds cash flow when they sell it into dollars, so the payoff to such an investor is the dollar cash flow it produces. To value this cash flow, assume that the U.S. investor contracts today to convert the
expected

cash flow in one period at the forward rate, for example $1.36/£. If we assume that spot exchange rates and the foreign currency cash flows of the security are uncorrelated, then this U.S. investor’s expected dollar cash flow is

nodes.text: This condition ought to look familiar, because
is simply covered interest parity (
), here derived for risky cash flows rather than risk-free cash flows.
Example 23.4 Present Values and Internationally Integrated Capital Markets
Problem

You are a U.S. investor trying to calculate the present value of a ¥10 million cash flow that will occur one year in the future. The spot exchange rate is ¥110/$ and the one-year forward rate is ¥105.8095/$. The appropriate dollar cost of capital for this cash flow is

nodes.text: . What is the dollar present value of the ¥10 million cash flow from the standpoint of a Japanese investor? What is the present value of the ¥10 million cash flow from the standpoint of a U.S. investor who first converts the ¥10 million into dollars and then applies the dollar discount rate?
Solution
Plan
For the Japanese investor, we can compute the present value of the future yen cash flow at the yen discount rate and use the spot exchange rate to convert that amount to dollars.
For the U.S. investor, we can convert the future yen cash flow to dollars at the forward rate and compute the present value using the dollar discount rate.
We know:

data.alt: StartLayout 1st Row  Future CF equals yen sign 10 million comma one hyphen year forward rate equals yen sign 105.8095 slash dollar sign 2nd Row  StartLayout 1st Row 1st Column r Subscript yen sign Superscript asterisk Baseline equals 0.05 2nd Column spot rate equals yen sign 110 dollar sign 2nd Row 1st Column r Subscript yen sign Superscript asterisk Baseline equals 0.01 2nd Column Blank EndLayout EndLayout

nodes.text: Execute
For the Japanese investor, the dollar present value of the yen cash flow is:

data.alt: StartFraction Yen Cash Flows Over left parenthesis 1 plus Yen Discount Rate right parenthesis EndFraction times Spot Rate equals StartFraction yen sign 10,000,000 Over 1.01 EndFraction times left parenthesis dollar sign 1 yen sign 110 right parenthesis equals dollar sign 90,009

nodes.text: For a U.S. investor who first converts the ¥10 million into dollars using the forward rate and then applies the dollar cost of capital:

data.mathML: <math display="block"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mtext>Yen Cash Flows</mtext><mo>×</mo><mtext>Forward Rate</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mtext>Dollar Discount Rate</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mo>¥</mo><mn>10,000,000</mn><mo>×</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mo>$</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mo>¥</mo><mn>105.8095</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>1.05</mn></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>=</mo><mo>$</mo><mn>90,009</mn></mrow></math>
data.alt: StartFraction Yen Cash Flows times Forward Rate Over left parenthesis 1 plus Dollar Discount Rate right parenthesis EndFraction equals StartFraction yen sign 10,000,000 times left parenthesis dollar sign 1 divided by yen sign 105.8095 right parenthesis Over 1.05 EndFraction equals dollar sign 90,009

nodes.text: Evaluate
Because the U.S. and Japanese capital markets are internationally integrated, both methods produce the same result.
Common Mistake: Forgetting to Flip the Exchange Rate
Note that in
Example 23.4
we had exchange rates in terms of yen per dollar, for example ¥110/$. However, we needed to convert yen into dollars, so we multiplied the present value in yen by the
reciprocal

of the exchange rate: $1/¥110. Note that this is the same as dividing the yen present value by ¥110/$ to find the number of dollars. It is common when working with exchange rates to lose track of which currency should be in the numerator and which should be in the denominator. It is best to always write down the cash flows along with their currency signs so that you can keep track of them. Then by crossing out currency signs as you go, you can be sure that you will be left with an answer in the correct currency:

data.mathML: <math display="block"><mtable columnalign="left"><mtr><mtd><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mtext>Yen Cash Flows</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mtext>Yen Discount Rate</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>×</mo><mtext>Spot Rate</mtext></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mn>10,000,000</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>1.01</mn></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>×</mo><mfenced><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mo>$</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>110</mn></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mo>$</mo><mn>90,009</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>
data.alt: StartLayout 1st Row  StartFraction Yen Cash Flows Over left parenthesis 1 plus Yen Discount Rate right parenthesis EndFraction times Spot Rate 2nd Row  equals StartFraction 10,000,000 Over 1.01 EndFraction times left parenthesis StartFraction dollar sign 1 Over 110 EndFraction right parenthesis equals dollar sign 90,009 EndLayout
